thread.title: College lockdown ends after reported gunman on loose in Mt Victoria, Wellington
thread.title_full: College lockdown ends after reported gunman on loose in Mt Victoria, Wellington

title: College lockdown ends after reported gunman on loose in Mt Victoria, Wellington
text:
College lockdown ends after reported gunman on loose in Mt Victoria, Wellington Last updated 14:25, February 2 2017 Robert Kitchin/Fairfax NZ 
A security guard keeps an eye out at Wellington East Girls' College. 
A Wellington college was put in lockdown while armed police hunted for a person spotted with a gun near the top of Mt Victoria. 
Wellington East Girls' College was advised to lock down around 12.45pm, shortly after armed officers were called to Lookout Rd, at the top of the hill overlooking central Wellington. 
The lockdown was called off at 2pm. John Nicholson 
Mount Victoria from behind Wellington East Girls' College. 
A police spokeswoman said there were no longer cordons in place, but police were still in the area, looking for the person who had been described. There was no confirmation that he or she had a firearm. 
The school's executive officer, Craig McWilliam, said the school had been asked by police to go into lockdown, and on their advice had since lifted it. 
A teacher on site said she was waiting for details of what happened. It was understood somebody saw a man with what looked like a pistol in the area. FAIRFAX NZ 
Armed police are looking for a man with a gun. 
The college, which was having its orientation day, said earlier on its website: "We have been informed by police that there has been a possible sighting of a man with a firearm in Mt Victoria. The police have advised us to initiate our lock down protocol. 
"Caregivers are advised to stay away from the school until further notice. We will communicate further information as we are advised by police. 
"Staff please stay in classrooms/buildings with students as per protocol." 
Just after 2pm, it said: "Police have advised us we can exit from lockdown and resume normal activities. 
"School will finish at the scheduled time today and end of day arrangements should be unaffected." 
Police said anybody who noticed suspicious activity or saw a person carrying a firearm should call 111. - Stuff
